_**Bugsy Malone**_ is a 1976 American-British [musical](/wiki/Musical_film
"Musical film") [gangster](/wiki/Mob_film "Mob film") [comedy
film](/wiki/Comedy_film "Comedy film"), directed by [Alan
Parker](/wiki/Alan_Parker "Alan Parker") and featuring only [child
actors](/wiki/Child_actor "Child actor"). Set in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), the film is loosely based on
events in New York and Chicago from the early 1920s to 1931 during
[Prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States "Prohibition in the
United States"), specifically the exploits of real-life
[gangsters](/wiki/Gangster "Gangster") like [Al Capone](/wiki/Al_Capone "Al
Capone") and [Bugs Moran](/wiki/Bugs_Moran "Bugs Moran"), as dramatized in
cinema. Parker lightened the subject matter considerably for the children's
market; in the U.S. the film received a [G rating](/wiki/MPAA_rating "MPAA
rating").

The film was Parker's feature-length [directorial
debut](/wiki/Directorial_debut "Directorial debut"), introduced actor [Scott
Baio](/wiki/Scott_Baio "Scott Baio"), and featured a 13-year old [Jodie
Foster](/wiki/Jodie_Foster "Jodie Foster").

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Plot")]

A mobster named Roxy Robinson is "splurged" by members of a gang, using rapid-
fire cream-shooting "splurge guns". Once splurged, a kid is "all washed up...
finished". [Speakeasy](/wiki/Speakeasy "Speakeasy") boss Fat Sam introduces
himself and Bugsy Malone, a boxing promoter with no money ("Bugsy Malone").

At Fat Sam's [speakeasy](/wiki/Speakeasy "Speakeasy"), there is much dancing
and singing ("Fat Sam's Grand Slam"). Fat Sam is worried that his rival Dandy
Dan will try to take control of the speakeasy. Blousey Brown, an aspiring
singer, has come for an audition, but Sam is too distracted to see her. Bugsy
meets Blousey when he trips over her luggage. He is smitten and flirts with
her. Fat Sam's is raided by Dandy Dan's men, who shoot up the place. Dandy
Dan's men continue to attack Fat Sam's empire, eventually taking away rackets
and splurging members of Fat Sam's gang. Fat Sam sends all his available men
to see if they can track down the guns. They are trapped at a laundry and all
are splurged by Dandy Dan's gang.

Bugsy returns to Fat Sam's to arrange a new audition for Blousey. Fat Sam's
girlfriend, the chanteuse Tallulah, makes a pass at him. Although Bugsy
rejects her flirtation, Tallulah plants a big kiss on Bugsy's forehead when
Blousey enters; Blousey is jealous. Fat Sam hires Blousey after her audition,
but she refuses to speak to Bugsy ("I'm Feelin' Fine").

Fat Sam hires Bugsy to accompany him to a meeting with Dandy Dan. The meeting
is a trap, but Bugsy helps Fat Sam escape. Gratefully, Fat Sam pays him $200.
Bugsy and Blousey reconcile and have a romantic outing on a lake; Bugsy
promises to take her to Hollywood. When he returns Sam's car to the garage, he
is attacked and his money is stolen. Bugsy is saved by Leroy Smith, who
assaults the attackers and drives them away. Bugsy realizes that Leroy has the
potential to be a great boxer. Bugsy introduces Leroy to Cagey Joe and helps
him train ("So You Wanna Be a Boxer?"). Fat Sam again seeks Bugsy's aid after
his assistant Knuckles is unintentionally killed. Bugsy resists, but Fat Sam
offers $400, enough money to keep his promise to Blousey. Blousey is
disappointed when she learns that Bugsy hasn't bought the tickets to
California yet ("Ordinary Fool"). Bugsy and Leroy follow Dandy Dan's men to a
warehouse, where the guns are being stashed. The two of them can't take the
place alone, so Bugsy recruits a large group of down-and-out workers at a soup
kitchen ("Down and Out").

They steal the crates of guns and take them to Fat Sam's, arriving just as
Dandy Dan's gang arrives. Chaos ensues as a massive splurge gun fight erupts,
covering everyone (except Bugsy and Blousey) with cream. Unarmed patrons throw
cream pies. The piano player is hit from behind and falls onto the keys,
striking a single bass note. The tone silences the room, and the cream-covered
crowd performs in a final number ("You Give a Little Love"). They realize they
can all be friends, and Bugsy and Blousey leave for Hollywood.

## Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Cast")]

  * [Scott Baio](/wiki/Scott_Baio "Scott Baio") as Bugsy Malone, an Italian-Irish ex-boxer/boxing scout.
  * [Florrie Dugger](/wiki/Florrie_Dugger "Florrie Dugger") as Blousey Brown, a sassy young dame interested in Hollywood.
  * [Jodie Foster](/wiki/Jodie_Foster "Jodie Foster") as Tallulah, Fat Sam's [gun moll](/wiki/Gun_moll "Gun moll"), the speakeasy's star [chanteuse](/wiki/Chanteuse "Chanteuse") and Bugsy's old flame.
  * [John Cassisi](/wiki/John_Cassisi "John Cassisi") as Fat Sam Staccetto, crime boss. He is dubbed by the press as "The Alleged Mobster King of the Lower East Side".
  * [Martin Lev](/wiki/Martin_Lev "Martin Lev") as Dandy Dan, rival gang boss who steals Fat Sam's territory.
  * Paul Murphy as Leroy Smith, an African-American tramp who discovers he has a talent for boxing
  * [Sheridan Earl Russell](/w/index.php?title=Sheridan_Earl_Russell_\(actor\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sheridan Earl Russell \(actor\) \(page does not exist\)") as Knuckles, Fat Sam's main hoodlum who constantly cracks his knuckles. The only character to actually be killed by the splurge as opposed to "finished".
  * Albin 'Humpty' Jenkins as Fizzy, Caretaker at Fat Sam's Grand Slam, tap dancer
  * Paul Chirelstein as Smolsky, dim-witted police captain
  * [Andrew Paul](/wiki/Andrew_Paul "Andrew Paul") as O'Dreary, dumb policeman
  * [Jeffrey Stevens](/wiki/Jeff_Stevenson_\(comedian\) "Jeff Stevenson \(comedian\)") as Louis, one of Fat Sam's hoodlums
  * Donald Waugh as Snake Eyes, one of Fat Sam's hoodlums
  * Peter Holder as Ritzy, one of Fat Sam's hoodlums
  * Michael Kirkby as Angelo, one of Fat Sam's hoodlums
  * [Dexter Fletcher](/wiki/Dexter_Fletcher "Dexter Fletcher") as Baby Face, down and out
  * Davidson Knight as Cagey Joe, the boxing gym owner
  * John Williams as Roxy Robinson, Fat Sam's best bodyguard, splurged by Dandy Dan's gang
  * [Bonnie Langford](/wiki/Bonnie_Langford "Bonnie Langford") as Lena Marelli, showy, pompous theatre performer
  * [Mark Curry](/wiki/Mark_Curry_\(television_presenter\) "Mark Curry \(television presenter\)") as Oscar DeVelt, stuck-up theatre producer
  * [Jonathan Scott-Taylor](/wiki/Jonathan_Scott-Taylor "Jonathan Scott-Taylor") as News Reporter

  * Vivienne McKone as Velma, showgirl, Tallulah's Troupe

## Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

_Bugsy Malone_ was [Alan Parker](/wiki/Alan_Parker "Alan Parker")'s first
feature film. Parker was trying to find a film project that was not
"parochial" and decided upon an American gangster setting: "I had four young
children and we used to go to a cottage in Derbyshire at weekends. On the
long, boring car journey up there, I started telling them the story of a
gangster called Bugsy Malone. They’d ask me questions and I’d make up answers,
based on my memories of watching old movie reruns as a kid." His eldest son
suggested children should be cast as the "heroes".[6]

### Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Casting")]

The director chose to cast several unknown actors in the film. To find his Fat
Sam, Parker visited a [Brooklyn](/wiki/Brooklyn "Brooklyn") classroom, asking
for "the naughtiest boy in class". The students were unanimous in selecting
[John Cassisi](/wiki/John_Cassisi "John Cassisi"), and Parker gave him the
role. Florrie Dugger (Blousey) was originally cast in a smaller role; when the
actress cast as Blousey suddenly grew taller than Baio, Dugger was promoted.
She had been "discovered" at [RAF Chicksands](/wiki/RAF_Chicksands "RAF
Chicksands"), an air force base in Bedfordshire where her American father was
stationed.[7] At the time of filming, all of the cast were under 17 years
old.[8]

Parker cast Baio after he slammed down the script and stormed out of his
audition.[6] Baio later remembered:

> I had quit the business, because I didn’t like driving into Manhattan. Well,
> the long and the short of it is that I wanted to play with my friends after
> school, but it happened to be raining that day, so I went to the city to
> meet with Alan Parker. I read it, but I just barely read it. I didn’t even
> want to be there. He was English, but I didn’t even know what that was. He
> was just this weird guy with long hair, and I didn’t know what he was.
> [Laughs.] So I sort of read the script, threw it at him, and walked out the
> door. That was it: I’d gotten the part before I got home.[9]

### Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Music")]

Parker chose [Paul Williams](/wiki/Paul_Williams_\(songwriter\) "Paul Williams
\(songwriter\)") to score the film in order to get a more "palatable" modern
sound, and simply because he liked him.[10] Williams had scored [Brian De
Palma](/wiki/Brian_De_Palma "Brian De Palma")'s commercial failure _[Phantom
of the Paradise](/wiki/Phantom_of_the_Paradise "Phantom of the Paradise")_ ,
but had also written huge pop-radio hits (such as "[We've Only Just
Begun](/wiki/We%27ve_Only_Just_Begun "We've Only Just Begun")" (lyrics), and
"[(Just An) Old Fashioned Love Song](/wiki/An_Old_Fashioned_Love_Song "An Old
Fashioned Love Song")"). In fact, Williams would soon win an
[Oscar](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award") for his song
"[Evergreen](/wiki/Evergreen_\(Love_Theme_from_A_Star_Is_Born\) "Evergreen
\(Love Theme from A Star Is Born\)")" from the film _[A Star Is
Born](/wiki/A_Star_Is_Born_\(1976_film\) "A Star Is Born \(1976 film\)")_
(1976).

Williams felt that "...the challenge for me was to provide songs that
reflected the period ... and yet maintained an energy that would hold the
young audiences attention." According to Parker, Williams was writing while on
tour, recording songs in different cities, and sending the completed tapes to
Hollywood. Arriving during the first pre-shoot rehearsals, the songs had to be
accepted and used as they were, with voices by Williams, Archie Hahn and
others.

Neither the director nor the songwriter was entirely comfortable with the
results. Williams later wrote "I'm really proud of the work and the only thing
I've ever doubted is the choice of using adult voices. Perhaps I should have
given the kids a chance to sing the songs." Parker also commented: "Watching
the film after all these years, this is one aspect that I find the most
bizarre. Adult voices coming out of these kids' mouths? I had told Paul that I
didn't want squeaky kids voices and he interpreted this in his own way.
Anyway, as the tapes arrived, scarcely weeks away from filming, we had no
choice but to go along with it!"[11]

### Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Filming")]

The film was rehearsed and shot in England, largely on [Pinewood
Studios](/wiki/Pinewood_Studios "Pinewood Studios")' "H" stage, with locations
in [Black Park Country Park](/wiki/Black_Park "Black Park") (Wexham,
Buckinghamshire) and Reading, Berkshire.

The "splurge firearm" proved to be problematic. After initial experiments with
cream-filled wax balls proved painful, Parker decided to abandon the idea of
filming the firearms directly. Instead, the firearms fired ping-pong balls,
and a [fast cut](/wiki/Fast_cutting "Fast cutting") to a victim being pelted
with "splurge" was used to convey the impression of the rapid-firing
firearms.[8]

Baio later said making the film was "awesome":

> A kid’s fantasy: You get to dress up as gangster, you get to shoot guns that
> fire whipped cream, you get to drive cars with pedals that look like real
> cars, and you get to talk like a grown-up. I mean, you couldn’t ask for a
> better first big gig. Talk about getting you hooked on a business! It was
> fantastic.[9]

## Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Release")]

_Bugsy Malone_ was released in late 1976 to generally positive reviews. On
[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), it currently holds
a score of 83% based on 18 reviews, with an average rating of 6.6/10.[12]
Despite the positive critical reception, _Bugsy Malone_ was not a commercial
success in the US, bringing in just over $2.7 million. Paramount gave it a
[limited release](/wiki/Limited_release "Limited release"), usually in second-
tier theaters in a double-bill with _[The Bad News
Bears](/wiki/The_Bad_News_Bears "The Bad News Bears")_ , which had already
been out for six months and was no longer much of a draw. According to Parker,
the film was "quite successful" in the United Kingdom. By 1985, it had earned
an estimated profit of £1,854,000.[3]

## Accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Accolades")]

The film garnered 15 award nominations, including "Best Motion Picture
(Musical/Comedy)", "Best Original Score" and "Best Original Song" (for the
title track) from the [Golden Globes](/wiki/Golden_Globe "Golden Globe"), and
an [Oscar](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards") for "[Best Original Song
Score](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Academy Award for Best
Original Score")" (Paul Williams). The film was in competition for the [Palme
d'Or](/wiki/Palme_d%27Or "Palme d'Or") at the [1976 Cannes Film
Festival](/wiki/1976_Cannes_Film_Festival "1976 Cannes Film Festival").[13]
Actress Jodie Foster received two [BAFTAs](/wiki/BAFTA "BAFTA"), "Best
Supporting Actress" and "Most Promising Newcomer to Leading Film Roles",
however, both her nominations were for her previous year's work in _Taxi
Driver_ in addition to her work on _Bugsy Malone_. [Alan
Parker](/wiki/Alan_Parker "Alan Parker") received the [BAFTA Award for Best
Original Screenplay](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Original_Screenplay "BAFTA
Award for Best Original Screenplay"), and a nomination for [Best
Direction](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Direction "BAFTA Award for Best
Direction"). [Geoffrey Kirkland](/wiki/Geoffrey_Kirkland "Geoffrey Kirkland")
won the [BAFTA Award for Best Production
Design](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Production_Design "BAFTA Award for Best
Production Design"). Additionally, [Paul
Williams](/wiki/Paul_Williams_\(songwriter\) "Paul Williams \(songwriter\)")
received a nomination for the [Anthony Asquith Award for Film
Music](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Film_Music "BAFTA Award for Best Film
Music"), and [Monica Howe](/wiki/Monica_Howe "Monica Howe") a Best Costume
Design nomination. The film itself received a Best Picture nomination.[14]

In 2008, the [American Film Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American
Film Institute") nominated this film for its [Top 10 Gangster Films
list](/wiki/AFI%27s_10_Top_10 "AFI's 10 Top 10").[15]

## Home media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Home media")]

In the early eighties, _Bugsy Malone_ was released on VHS. On 16 April 1996,
it was re-released by Paramount on VHS. Although the film has never been
commercially released on Region 1 DVD, it has been available through Internet
sites as an Asian import supporting Region 1 (US). On 9 September 2008,
Arista/SME released a [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc") version,
encoded for "all regions", as a United Kingdom import. This edition includes a
[director's commentary](/wiki/Audio_commentary "Audio commentary") as well as
other special features, however, as of October 2009, the Blu-ray version was
discontinued. A US DVD (Region 1) release was listed around 2003/04 as being
available soon, however the film has yet to be released in this format.

## Soundtrack[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Soundtrack")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d1/Bugsy_Malone-
CD_soundtrack.jpg/250px-Bugsy_Malone-
CD_soundtrack.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bugsy_Malone-CD_soundtrack.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bugsy_Malone-CD_soundtrack.jpg "Enlarge")

CD cover

The album was originally released as an [LP](/wiki/LP_album "LP album") in
1976. In March 1996, [Polydor UK](/wiki/Polydor_Records#Polydor_UK "Polydor
Records") released the soundtrack on CD. It has yet to be released in the US
on CD but is available through various outlets as an import.

Performers include [Paul Williams](/wiki/Paul_Williams_\(songwriter\) "Paul
Williams \(songwriter\)"), [Archie Hahn](/wiki/Archie_Hahn_\(actor\) "Archie
Hahn \(actor\)"), [Julie McWhirter](/wiki/Julie_McWhirter "Julie McWhirter"),
and [Liberty Williams](/wiki/Liberty_Williams "Liberty Williams"). The track
listing is:

  1. "Bugsy Malone" – Paul Williams
  2. "Fat Sam's Grand Slam" – Paul Williams
  3. "Tomorrow"
  4. "Bad Guys"
  5. "I'm Feeling Fine"
  6. "My Name Is Tallulah" \- Louise "Liberty" Williams
  7. "So You Wanna Be a Boxer?"
  8. "Ordinary Fool"
  9. "Down and Out"
  10. "You Give a Little Love" – Paul Williams

A cast recording of the [National Youth Music
Theatre](/wiki/National_Youth_Music_Theatre "National Youth Music Theatre")
stage version of _Bugsy Malone_ was released in 1998. Like the stage show,
this recording featured two songs originally written by Williams, but not used
in the film: "That's Why They Call Him Dandy" and "Show Business". There is
also some additional incidental orchestral score, such as an _Overture_ and
_Exit Music_ , with music arranged by John Pearson.

## Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Legacy")]

In 2003, _Bugsy Malone_ was voted #19 on a list of the 100 greatest musicals,
as chosen by viewers of Channel 4 in the UK, placing it higher than _[The
Phantom of the Opera](/wiki/The_Phantom_of_the_Opera_\(1986_musical\) "The
Phantom of the Opera \(1986 musical\)")_ , _[Cats](/wiki/Cats_\(musical\)
"Cats \(musical\)")_ , and _[The King and I](/wiki/The_King_and_I "The King
and I")_.[16] _Bugsy Malone_ ranks 353rd on _[Empire
Magazine](/wiki/Empire_Magazine "Empire Magazine")_ 's 2008 list of the 500
greatest movies of all time.[17]

_Bugsy Malone_ has been adapted into a stage show in two forms.[18][19] A 2003
television documentary called _Bugsy Malone: After They Were Famous_ features
a reunion and interviews with Jodie Foster, Scott Baio, John Cassisi and
Florrie Dugger. The British actors who played Fat Sam's gang are also reunited
at [Pinewood Studios](/wiki/Pinewood_Studios "Pinewood Studios").[20] The
documentary reported that Dugger, who (unlike her co-stars) had never acted
again, had chosen to pursue a career in the [United States Air Force Medical
Service](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force_Medical_Service "United States Air
Force Medical Service").[21][7]

In 2010, UK band [Silvery](/wiki/Silvery "Silvery") included a cover of "You
Give a Little Love" on their second album 'Railway Architecture', and [Olly
Murs](/wiki/Olly_Murs "Olly Murs"), runner up in the 2009 UK series of _[The X
Factor](/wiki/The_X_Factor_\(UK\) "The X Factor \(UK\)")_ , sampled "So You
Wanna Be a Boxer" in his song "Hold On" that can be found on his [debut
album](/wiki/Olly_Murs_\(album\) "Olly Murs \(album\)").

In 2011, the film was the most screened film in [secondary
schools](/wiki/Secondary_school "Secondary school") in the United Kingdom.[22]

In 2017, the song "You Give A Little Love" was sung by a children's chorus at
the end of a Netflix "Black Mirror" episode (Season 4 episode 3 "Crocodile").

## Stage
adaptation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bugsy_Malone&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Stage adaptation")]

Parker wrote the book for a stage adaptation of _Bugsy Malone_ , using
Williams' music. This premiered in the [West End](/wiki/West_End_theatre "West
End theatre") in 1983 at [Her Majesty's Theatre](/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Theatre
"Her Majesty's Theatre") and ran for 300 performances. It was directed by
[Michael Dolenz](/wiki/Michael_Dolenz "Michael Dolenz") and the cast featured
[Catherine Zeta-Jones](/wiki/Catherine_Zeta-Jones "Catherine Zeta-Jones") as
Tallulah. In 1997, the [National Youth Music
Theatre](/wiki/National_Youth_Music_Theatre "National Youth Music Theatre")
mounted an all-youth version. It was revived at the [Queen's
Theatre](/wiki/Queen%27s_Theatre "Queen's Theatre") in 1997, starring
[Sheridan Smith](/wiki/Sheridan_Smith "Sheridan Smith") and [Jamie
Bell](/wiki/Jamie_Bell "Jamie Bell").[23] Another revival played in 2015 and
again in 2016 at the [Lyric Hammersmith](/wiki/Lyric_Hammersmith "Lyric
Hammersmith") theatre,[24] where it was nominated for the [Olivier
Award](/wiki/Olivier_Award "Olivier Award") for best musical revival.[25]
